reviewText: Needless to say the acting is great, the script is clever and the plot keeps you guessing till the very end. While this is no "Godfather", on the other hand there ain't no horse's head in the bed either.

"I can't do what I said I would do." Val (Pacino) has just been released from prison and his friend Doc (Walken) is there to pick him up. He want's to give Val everything he wants on his first day of freedom. Doc's problem is that he has until 10 a.m. to kill his friend or wind up dead himself. I was really looking forward to seeing this one. As you know I am a huge Pacino fan and am a little biased, but I really enjoyed this. It was both funny and a little moving at times. Pacino, Walken and Arkin are a great team and I would love to see them in a movie together again. There are some absolute hilarious parts to this mixed in with some great action scenes. There really is something in this for everyone and even those who are a little older will like this. Kind of like a Space Cowboys for criminals. Even though you can guess how the movie will end about a half hour in it still keeps you watching and is enjoyable the whole way through. Overall, a hugely entertaining movie that I highly recommend, funny and full of action and drama. Cast is great. I give it an A-.

With Stand-up Guys we are given three great actors in three great performances. The fact that they are not necessarily great roles is really beside the point. The stars have enough personality and we enough affection for them to overcome most obstacles, let alone such a minor one.

Stand-up Guys is a movie that depends on so much on it's performers more than anything else, really. Directed by actor Fisher Stevens, it's easy enough to assume that he loves actors, but that he knows when to stay out of the way of these actors is a testament to his craft.

Stand-up Guys could be easily dismissed as a "grump old gangsters". However, that would be missing the point and the amusement to be found here. A funny movie, but not absurdly so, it's not a laugh riot. But it doesn't need to be, it's charming and humorous enough.

Working from a rather leaden script by Noah Halde. None of this matters because the talented cast knows how to rise above the material and thus carry the movie further than the material.

Unlike a lot of recent similar themed movies, Stand-up Guys does not feature aging actors acting as though time has stood still. In fact, much of Stand-up Guys depends upon their ages. It's able to be a mediation on death, friendship, loyalty and the inevitable passage of time. It's rather poignant in it's own way.

Watching these actors I realized just how important to me hey re, I've been watching them o decades. Now, Stand-up Guys makes us realize that we are watching them enter into their twilight, soon they will fade from our screens, but not our hearts. A movie like Stand-up Guys  is really more about us the audience re living something.

Pacino plays Val, who as the movie starts is just realized from prison. He served 28 years for the accidental killing of a mobster's son during a heist, h didn`t rat out his accomplices because he's a stand-up guy . There to meet him is one of his old cronies, Doc (Walken), who is possible his only friend.

Val wants to "party", Doc says he's retired, not just from being a thief from everything else. Of course, this doesn't stop from breaking into just about every place he goes, but it's mostly places like a pharmacy "my co-pay on this one is insane".

Val knows the gangster who's son he killed will have him killed. He knows that Doc has been ordered to it. But this isn't about him trying to out wit or out gun his old friend. He just wants to have one last good time. He knows if he doesn't do it, someone else will anyway.

So the two head into the night in a serious of unlikely events, but they are fun to watch none the less. They  spring their other buddy, they're former getaway driver, Hirsch (Arkin). Not from prison, but from the nursing home that he lives in. They need a driver to go into the night.

This leads to a lot of cute and funny situations. Like an improbable car chase on the freeway with the police. I am so burnt out on car chases, but this one is different. It's not about the getaway or the chase, but who's driving.

Stand-up Guys doesn't depend so much on it's story as it does on it's personalities. And there is personality to spare. This is Pacino and Walken's movie, both at the top of their form, the best I've seen them in years. Arkin adds support in a smaller role, but it is amazing how he lights up the screen, and has been doing so wonderfully lately in a serious of excellent films.

I also like that Stand-up Guys comes to it's logical conclusion, in an ending that is perfectly handled and fitting. So many fine movies are ruined by a third act that is forced or contrived. The dreaded third act problem, as I like to call it. But not here, the ending is most correct.

You will notice that I am giving Stand-up Guys four stars, despite some rather immense flaws. But the truth is that while I watched Stand-up Guys, I was never aware of them. The actors held my attention, I was so captivate by their mesmerizing work as to be lost to everything else.

The story may be obvious. The movie is predictable. But never once did I find myself actually thinking about it. I was to busy watching the people on screen, the actors make them flesh and blood.

The late George C. Scott said at  to judge a performance that he looks for the joy in it. If an actors is able to enjoy himself and convey it to a paying audience, he has done a good job. There is a lot of joy, it's easy to see. And we get into enjoy these stars once more before they slip into the night.

see my reviews at moviezonemagazine.com

Three  criminals reunite to recapture the glory of their lawless youth, but find their celebrations interrupted when one is put into a difficult position by a vengeful mob boss. Nearly 20 years after refusing to inform on his partner-in-crime, Val (Al Pacino) emerges from prison a free man. Waiting for him at the gate is his old friend Doc (Christopher Walken), who quickly takes him out on the town with the mischievous Hirsh (Alan Arkin) to stir up some trouble.  Good movie well acted.  I enjoyed watching the forever young Al Pacino.

"Stand Up Guys" (2013 release; 94 min.) starts with Val (played by Al Pacino) being released from jail after a 28 year stint. He's awaited by his best friend Doc (played by Christopher Walken). We later find out that Val was in jail for the killing of the son of tough guy Claphands, and that Claphands has hired Doc to take out Val by 10 am the next morning. The movie plays out entirely in the 24 hrs. between Val's release from jail and the next morning. During that time we see the two old buddies "liven it up", leading to sometime funny (if at times predictable, as in: Viagra overdose consequences, etc.), and sometimes sentimential moments about the "bad old days" (when they get ready to take on some baddies, they look at each other and start humming: "It's time to kick ass or time to chew gum! but I've run out of gum", ha!).

Several comments: the only plot line that matters in the entire movie is whether at the end Doc takes out Val (I'm not going to tell you how it ends, you'll have to see for yourself how it all plays out). Far more important and enjoyable are the acting performances. Let's start with Al Pacino, who seems like he's having the time of his life and is feisty and fiery throughout. Christopher Walken brings a more restrained, but equally effective, performance. But the person who steals the movie is, once again, Alan Arkin in a fairly small role (he gets rescued/abducted from a seniors home by Val and Doc). Arkin seems to be everywhere these days (he's likely to win the Oscar for Best Supporting Actor for his role in Argo).

Bottom line: this movie was okay, but could've been even better with a better script and tighter direction. The theatre where I saw this at here in Cincinnati tonight (1st day of release) was very poorly attended, leading me to believe that it's doubtful this movie will find a large audience. So if you are interested in this movie, better hurry before it's gone (or simply wait for the DVD release later this year).

I was lucky to attend a screening of ,Stand Up Guys', a thriller-comedy with Al Pacino and Christopher Walken. The movie is hilarious with lots of funny scenes and dialogues. Especially Al Pacino shows method acting at its best. He doesn't play - he is the low rank veteran mobster Val, who - fresh out of prison - wants to make the best of his last hours on earth. Val's only friend Doc is the exact opposite. He looks like a living dead while he is following Val through the night. Doc has a job to do and his job is to kill Val until the next morning. He doesn't have a choice. The mafia don, who wants to see Val dead, has threatened to kill Doc's niece, if Doc spares his friend's life. The world seems to press on Doc's shoulders. Val, on the other hand, knows for whom the bell tolls, but he's a ,Stand Up Guy' and so is his friend.

Director Fisher Stephens arranged extremely funny and dramatic scenes in a quick succession, but his best decision was to step back and let these guys play. Fantastic - don't miss this gem!

Stand Up Guys is a surprisingly good film, with great acting all around, but it does take some time to get into it.  For me I find that when left to his own devices Al Pacino does nothing but go too far over the top, which he does, in my humble opinion, near the beginning of the film.  By the time Alan Arkin joins Pacino and Walken as a trio, Al's character becomes more subtle and thus tolerable (and not chewing scenery) and remains that way for the rest of the film.

For some laughs, good drama, action, and a heartwarming story to boot...I recommend this movie.

I give it a very generous three stars out of respect for the caliber of actors in this film. The plot isn't very intricate nor does it try to be. It's just a film about a newly released mobster who reunites with his "retired" best friend to enjoy what may be his last day alive. The film is a weird mix of comedy and drama (weird because it doesn't quite flow like alot of other dramadies where each moment, comedy or drama has its own time to reflect on itself). Even the better comedic moments in this film don't seem to take full advantage of its potential because there's always a sense of impeding drama. And likewise with the dramatic moments, they also have a sense of humor to them. Overall, a decent film that doesn't break any new ground but puts together some legendary actors for one more go at it.

Ignore the negative reviews about this film, all from Millennials with the brains of a slow fifth-grader.  You could describe this movie as "Space Cowboys" with guns, but it's far more than that.  It's actually a love story, the bond between lifelong friends that usually goes unspoken, except in times of utter desperation.  The fact that they're all criminals is just what they do for a living, beyond the bounds "normal" people.  The ties that bind go far beyond mere surface morals and definitions of "good" and "bad," but to the very core of human emotions and existence.  I loved this homage to nearly every crime drama worth watching, but given a twist and sense of humor and humanity that extends well beyond the cliche.  The acting, the characters, and the writing... is timeless.  This film, like good wine, seems to get better with each successive taste.
the only thing about this film that is more disappointing than actually watching it is that you're forced to give it at least a 1 star rating.

Four and a half SERENDIPITOUS Stars. This 2013 crime dramedy finds three longtime senior citizen criminal friends getting together like old times when one is released from prison after decades. A very busy, adventurous night, ensues. But there is a more than meets the eye going on as there is a tragic catch which underscores the entire night. Starring a great triumvirate of acting legends giving highly satisfying performances: Al Pacino, Christopher Walken, and Alan Arkin, with Julianna Margulies, Mark Margolis, Lucy Punch, Addison Timlin, Vanessa Ferlito, Katheryn Winnick, Bill Burr, and more. Directed by Fisher Stevens. Highly Recommended. Four and a half MEMORABLE Stars. (Lionsgate, Sidney Kimmel Entertainment, Lakeshore Entertainment. Rated R. Color. HD. CC. Time-2 hours.)

How can a movie starring Christopher Walken, Al Pacino, and Alan Arkin be such a major disappointment? Because it's totally boring. I kept waiting for the comedy to happen. And waiting, and waiting. What I got was a ludicrous Viagra-caused priapism joke. Two major plot points were visible miles away. A major disappointment at worst, mediocre at best. Walken was totally wasted in this with a character with the least amount of dialogue among the three major stars. And instead of should have been an action-filled climax is rendered cheaply off camera. This whole film reeks of production done on the cheap with characters you never warm up to. Avoid.

Two favorite actors getting a chance to have fun and shoot guns. It seemed like they didn't have a script but they made up their own idea of a story. It was fun to watch Al Pacino and Christopher Walken flow through the plot like two guys being handed a old pair of shoes that felt good to them. The plot was mediocre but the actors brought some life to the story.  Both actors clearly had a great time at the end.  It was supposed to be a comedy, but it was not the one where you would fall on the floor laughing. It was one where there were chuckles and then fun just watching two masters work out a poor script. Both are excellent in just about anything and this was one of these "anythings".  How can you NOT love Al Pacino?

This is one of those movies where I don't understand all the acclaim. The film covers a day in the life of two friends, one of who was just paroled. They drive, eat, and talk. They meet up with a third friend. They drive, eat, and talk. There's a brief gunfight, and the credits roll. There's a bit more, but not much. The movie is carried by the strength and history of the actors, and with other people, it would be almost unwatchable. I love these guys, but not for this.

This is one of those small budget movies with big name stars that will definitely want make you want to stay put (at home) for a night glued to the big screen.  Al Pacino, Christopher Walken and Alan Alda  play three gangsters -- way past their prime.  One is fresh out of prison after spending 28 years there, another one is enjoying his humble retirement in not so appealing apartment and the third one is spending his last days in the retirement home sucking on oxygen.  These are wise guys with class.  They are old school.  But as their past is catching up with them, they have one night to make up for the years of loneliness and regret - before they can bail out with a bang, literally.

It is smart movie with actors who pull it off with their personalities and wit.  Not too heavy of a movie and just a simple pleasure watching these three extraordinary actors at work.

If you like any of or all of the three main characters, then that is reason enough to watch this movie. I happen to like all three of these  oft brilliant actors. While not particularly brilliant, in my opinion, in this movie, they deliver a quirky tale of comic redemption of three aging gangsters. Now, I use the definition of the word comic which some dictionaries idiotically, authoritarianly and incorrectly claim is obsolete. That definition is the definition of comedy: a theatrical or literary piece portraying the life of the common man. In contrast, tragedy is a theatrical or literary  piece depicting the life and fate of the great and powerful. Comedy, therefore, contains funny or light hearted as well as dramatic moments. Tragedy, on the other hand, depicts only dramatic events, events which shape and ruin the lives of the great and powerful. So, this piece was a comedy. Common men who are gangsters, aging gangsters who comedically or comically go out with a bang. Thus, all three do this very well and the movie is worth watching if for no other reason than to see three great aging actors who are still making immensely watchable movies.

An overlooked guy film with two experienced actors who are comfortable with themselves and with each other. It is a story designed for those of us who have followed these graduates of the Lee Strasburg school of method acting and love good writing, excellent acting and films which have no need for CG and violence to move a story along. I bought a copy  and sent them to a friend who I consider my brother and have known him since 1966. He and I can pick up the phone after having not spoken for six months and it seems liked we just talked last weekend. That is what this film is all about.

Humorously interesting tale about some over the hill small time con guys who get together for a last fling. Very entertaining with a cast of some of our most beloved icons.

The story is a very good one and all three of the main actors Walken, Pacino, and Arkin do a great job in their acting.  All three are hard in their life and yet have a soft and vulnerable side that is makes you root for each of them.  The language is pretty intense (maybe unnecessarily) and some of the themes are definitely adult only, but despite those things the story of friendship, loyalty, family, and devotion make the story one that, like a good book, I didn't want to put down and didn't want to end.

Stand Up Guys is yet another example of a contemporary film sabotaged by its own marketing. The ads presented it as an action-comedy, when in fact it's a much more melancholy and pensive story about ageing, loyalty, and family. It's beautifully lit and shot by Michael Grady, and Fisher Stevens' direction interweaves comedic and dramatic pacing to good effect. And while the film has its flaws, the performances by Pacino and Walken, who are playing characters rather than caricatures, are worth your time. In some ways, Stand Up Guys reminds me of Scorcese's After Hours and Landis' Into the Night, and not only because it takes place over the course of 24 hours, but because of its quirky, original characters and its genre blending.
This is a sleeper and many folks probably have not heard of it.  Worth a look!

That said it would probably be more fun watching them in their prime than dragging their feet over a last hurrah, but that's what this movie is about.  Fighting back death as it inevitably creeps up on everyone.  I don't care what people say, it's not a great movie, but it's not horrible either. Other than being a vehicle to showcase 3 of America's best actors whom I'm sure could have phoned this in and had their paycheck mailed to them, this film is a real dog.  Yes, there are some funny and touching moments, but apart from that,it's just plain stupid. Of the three main actors, Pacino stands out as the weakest, performing a cliched impression of Al Pacino.  Alan Arkin is a master of subtlety, and Christopher Walken never fails to crack me up even in films where he not supposed to be funny.  The final scene, yet another movie cliche, was done much better in Thelma and Louise and in Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid.  I'm just glad that I did not pay to see this crap in a theater.

Elderly former wise guys reunite when one gets out of prison after 28 years, and have a wild night with Russian hookers, a rape victim and her attackers, a stolen sports car, and another elderly hoodlum who wants revenge. They break into a drug store, a clothing store, and a warehouse, eat three ever-escalating meals in the same all-night cafe, served by the same sweet young waitress, and generally misbehave. It's ridiculous but oddly sweet, in a way that Jason Statham will never be able to deliver at that age.

I'll say up front that only a odd-choice finale keeps it from being a five star.
Aside from that, this is a great indie-feeling film that manages to shift tone seamlessly from dumb laughs, to clever comedy, to a smart and thoughtful look friendship and being old in a world that's starting to move past you.
Works on every level it tries to, and Pacino hasn't put this much effort in for quite awhile.

What is it that makes "Standup Guys" work as a comedy? You might have noticed in the movie allusions to other movies -- "Scent of a Woman" was one I caught, and the aging Randolph Scott and Joel McCrea in "Ride the High Country" seemed to be alluded to at the end. There's even, I think, a perverse allusion to "The Untouchables." I'm sure people who have seen more movies than I have caught more. You'll remember the Shakespeare plots that are premised on an outrageous demand? -- "Marry the man I want you to marry or you'll have to be put to death" ("Midsummer Night's Dream"), for example. Here Doc (Christopher Walken) has been ordered by his former boss, Claphands (Mark Margolis, looking like Ron Paul!), to kill his old friend Val (Pacino) when he (Val) finishes up his 28 year prison sentence. Claphands believes Val to have been responsible for the death of his son during a shoot-out with police, and while it seems unlikely that Val really killed the young man, he took the fall and didn't rat out the others. In other words, he's a standup guy, and yet Claphands -- 28 years on, for heaven's sake -- wants him dead and wants his best friend to kill him. Premises don't get much more outrageous than that. The action of the movie takes place in the day, approximately, between Val's release and the time of Claphands's deadline. Val learns about his predicament early in the movie and accepts that Doc will have to kill him.

What clues us to the fact that we're not in the world of "realism," however, is the fact that neither Doc nor Val spend the rest of the movie trying to solve the problem. There is no "plot" -- the sequence of events is just a piece of machinery that enables the main characters to get together and do a lot of talking. They spend a lot of time in a diner in which Doc's grand-daughter is a waitress who doesn't know that the old regular that she serves frequently is her grandfather. There are visits to a brothel that doesn't look like any brothel of the present day, the madam of which is young woman who looks like a stereotypical movie secretary and where Eastern-European prostitutes seem happy in their work. Val and Doc "rescue" their old buddy Hirsch (Alan Arkin) from an assisted-living facility. When they walk in, he's hooked up to an oxygen tank, and when he sees them, he just unhooks it, walks out, and takes them for a joyride in a stolen car that belongs to a couple of gangsters. Inside the trunk, after a bit of joyriding, they find a naked girl named Sylvia (Vanessa Ferlito), whom they free, feed, and then give a hilarious opportunity to get back at the gangsters who kidnapped her. Then they find Hirsch dead at the wheel. Then they bury him, with the help of his daughter Nina (Julianna Margulies), a nurse who had earlier helped Val when he had had to be hospitalized following a Viagra overdose. Then they steal some suits. Then they go to church, and Val tips the priest for trying to hear his confession . . . I think you might realize that we're in something like Coen Brothers or Bill Forsythe country. Of course, we realize that Claphands can't be avoided . . . but we notice too that nothing that Val and Doc actually DO seems to directed at solving the Claphands problem, even though they frequently discuss their predicament.

So what's the point? It is, I think, all about performance. It's clear fairly early that "standup guy" is a double-entendre. The comedy of Val's "performance", or lack thereof, in the brothel sets the tone, and on a later visit to the brothel with Hirsch, we see another kind of performance -- one of the most charming moments in the movie, in which we realize, if we think about it, that it's all about acting. And so is the movie -- the inconsequential actions that make up the "plot" exist solely to show us that two old actors can hold our attention in these moments. Whatever tone a scene requires, they're up for it, and they can seemingly shift at will. The dialogue is fresh: my favorite line might be "Who made you the arbiter of who has to give away their pants?" That could be right out of a Bill Forsythe movie. And Pacino and Walken (and Arkin when he's with them) are magical. The lighting does nothing to hide (in fact accentuates) the ravages of age, but whatever kind of performances might deteriorate with age, acting performances aren't necessarily among them. Although Walken goes through most of the movie looking like death warmed over, the movie is in fact a cheerful tribute to old movies, old actors, and absurd plots that we can be charmed in spite of. As for the ending, you can make of it (as Shakespeare might say) "what you will."

Before "discovering" Stand Up Guys my most positive recollections of Fisher Stevens are of his inspired and genuinely comical character Ben Jabituya in the two "Short Circuit" movies.  He was the standout cast member in both the 1986 original film and the 1988 sequel.  Since then, I've only seen him in very brief, somewhat uninspired film appearances.  But, based upon his direction of Stand Up Guys, Mr. Stevens is worthy of very high accolades.  Ben Jabitua may have faded away, but Fisher Stevens, re-emerging as a film director, is orders of magnitude brighter than many who aspire to direct motion pictures.  The plot of Stand Up Guys deals with three likeable career criminals, ostensibly retired, re-connecting late in life.  The story is both touching and funny, reminiscent of the Disney classics of old, but never as over-the-top as the Disney classics tended to become at times.

Stand up guys(released Oct/12)stars,among others, Al Pacino,Christopher Walken,Alan Arkin and Julianna Margulies. This film is a nice jaunt and pleasant journey with some old pros,making it all look effortless. I never thought I'd be calling the three main stars "old",but " time waits for no man",as Pacino says.
The story finds Pacino getting out of prison for a 28 year stretch he did for the accidental killing of his bosses son during a heist. The boss,Clap hands,doesn't quite remember it as an accident and has been waiting all those years for revenge on Pacino. Walken is there to greet his old pal who we find out,after they get back to Walken's place,is the one Clap hands has designated as the one to ice Pacino.
But Pacino wants to par-tay. Walken takes him to a local brothel the two frequented many years before. In fact the daughter of the original owner now runs it. Oops,but Pacino can't get the pipes working. Off the two go to the local drugstore to get some Viagra,and other sundries Walken needs. Pacino takes a slew  of the pills and not only gets things straight at the brothel but cannot "relax".They end up at a club and then back in the car where Pacino passes out. Walken tries but cannot bring himself to shoot his old buddy,He wakes him up and they go to the hospital to emerge where the daughter of an old friend, Hirsch,is tending to Pacino's problem. With that fixed they attend a restaurant Walken has frequented for years. They are served by a friendly waitress who Walken has obviously knows quite well. It is then Walken is forced to fess up that it is indeed HE that is the one that is supposed to kill Pacino;by 10AM that morning.
After their meal they steal a souped up car from some local scum bag hoodlums,"animals" as Walken calls them,and they look up their old pal Hirsch(Arkin),who used to be their getaway driver. Hirsch is now on oxygen but is very glad to see his old pals. The two talk Hirsch into driving their newly acquired car for them. While out they get set on by the police. After a brief chase Hirsch easily loses them. Next they head to the brothel,where Hirsch wants to have a three some. With the deed done the three head back onto the road. Not soon after they hear a banging from the trunk. It turns out to be a naked girl. They take her to the diner and get her something to eat. She explains that she was kidnapped by this gang and raped at a warehouse, then put in the trunk. Pacino and Walken say there must be consequences for such despicable behaviour,so they drive back and find the place where it happened. The girl is determined to come in with them but they finally persuade her to stay out for about ten minutes until things are under control. The two storm in and subdue all five guys,most tied up, with one on the floor. The girl comes in with a baseball bat and Pacino and Walken leave her to do her thing.
Back at the car the two find their old friend dead at the wheel. They go back to the hospital and tell his daughter what has happened. She agrees to Pacino's request to bury him that night. After a brief ceremony the two return to the diner. There Pacino guesses that the waitress Walken is so fond of is his granddaughter. While Walken makes a call to Clap hands for some clemency,his granddaughter sits down to talk to Pacino about her friend. Needless to say Clap hands isn't in a forgiving mood and holds Walken to his job. Walken writes a note to his granddaughter and pins the note,along with his apartment keys,to the bulletin board next to the phone and both men leave.
Next the two stop off at a church where Pacino goes to confession. Their next stop is a clothing store,where they both pick up some new suits. Part way through two of Clap hands thugs enter and Walken and Pacino  subdue them both,leaving one wounded in the hand and the other to send back to their boss. Meanwhile the waitress is now in Walken's apartment and the phone rings. She picks it up and Walken tells her that he loves her,and to get a shoe box in his closet. It is filled with cash. Walken tells her the unit is now hers and that some very beautiful paintings of sunrises he had done over the years were all inspired by her. Asked  if she will see him soon,he replies he doesn't know and hangs up.
The two now head down to Clap hands warehouse where they start a fire fight with two thugs outside then train their fire on Clap hands upstairs. As the gun fight continues the camera pans upward and over the building to a beautiful sunset,which then solidifies into one of Walken's paintings.
The major element that binds this film together is the chemistry between the two main leads,and Walken and Pacino have it from start to finish. Walken is continually torn between the respect he has for his old partner and the terrible job that Clap hands is forcing him to do. You can see it in his face at all times. And Pacino knows that his time is limited and tries to enjoy what little time he has,knowing all along it is his buddy that has to do the job. At one point he even breaks down thinking about it, in a vulnerable moment. Every other actor that comes on and off screen are strong and match the vibes of of both men,from Hirsch,Hirsch's daughter,Walkens granddaughter,the thugs,etc. The film takes place over about a 20 hour arc,counting the time from which Pacino walks out of jail. It is a well paced but steady progression as we wonder what the ending will be to all of the circumstances before us. The ending will come as kind of a cheat to some,but in retrospect it is fitting and smart,leaving it to our imaginations.
Technically speaking the film is in its original a/r of 2:35:1 and is clear and crisp .Extras include deleted scenes,interviews with the cast,a look at the stunt driving,behind the scenes,two featurettes and a look at some of Bon Jovi's music.
All in all a delightful film with two pros doing what comes naturally. There is great chemistry all around and the film fits like an old sweater. Recommended. 4-4 1/2 stars.

Loved the movie and the actors were top notch. Would definitely recommend. The plot was interesting as were the character portrayals,
Elite actors in an awful movie. The characters were pitiful sad and hopefully forgetful. I had one conversation about this movie and that this comment. No more
I love the line up of stars in this movie, but there was just something missing to make it great.

This movie is absolute crap! I purchased it based on the actors and the thought that with the 3 of them- Pacino,Walken& Arkin it was bound to be a goodie,well It is awful- I am yet to get thru the entire movie and believe me, I have tried- Many times! All I can say is,Pacino is ridiculous in the role he plays,which is made to over shadow the other 2 actors,when by far Walken is the better actor in the role he plays, Arkin just gets lost- because the main character and the bad acting by Pacino ruins it all. I learned a lesson in buying this movie without really knowing what it was about and just going on the  presumtion that Pacino is good in anything,and that it would be even better with the other 2 actors I like, Not true! actually was so bad I realized Pacino has lost his luster and really isn't nice to watch on screen anymore,and clearly doesn't pick roles with much challenge other than to try to out shine the other characters.

I typically enjoy anything starring Al Pacino, Christopher Walken or Allan Arkin, however Stand Up Guys was a bit...flat. While Walken was.  his.  USUAL.  oddball.  self., Pacino and Arkin seemed less than present, almost as if their killer spirit was a tad bit lost. Julianne Marguiles' character was somewhat softer than the roles she usually plays.

The story line (three retired hit man type guys who are looking for one last hoorah) was interesting enough and is definitely worth adding to your watch list for some got-nothing-better-to-do Saturday night when you want to see a movie that won't induce a complete coma of boredom, but it's certainly no blockbuster hit, which is probably why I never heard of it until I was browsing my Amazon Prime app.
Exsellent movie,lot's of fun, a good action, Al Pacino still a good actor,I love it good movie to watch,watch it you gonna like it.
It was great to see these 3 together for a decent little film.  Enjoyed every minute and would like to see another film of the same type.
Half hearted attempts..., except Pacino, he gave and gave. Hey, silly plot, perhaps a waste of production money. Reminded me of grumpy old men, which was funnier.

But i loved this movie. They don't pretend to be nice guys. They live in a world of 'not-nice' guys. Not people you'd want to do business with but they'd give you their last penny if you needed it.  The movie pulls no punches. It's good.to the last drop.  You're left feeling good that these guys, friends, care about each other, despite their lives, their pasts and what one is currently being forced to do to the other. And that's what you're kept wondering as these two put that aside and have their reunion as if this fact is nothing at all.  It almost becomes incidental oddly enough. The friendship and ensuing 'fun' is had despite the necessity of one having to rub the other out.

Alan Arkin was hilarious, Pacino and Walken good, but I didn't feel the chemistry at all.  Walken is so distinctive as an actor (weird, in a good way), that I don't think you can pair him with just anyone.
It was a little slow in the begining, but the acting was very good. The movie demonstrates a certain code of honor & loyalty among thieves, and also how that has changed today like everything else.

It kept popping up as one of my recommendations but I always kept scrolling.  I watched this on a Sunday with nothing to do for a few hours and to kill some time.  I honestly do not recall when it came to theaters, but I wish I had seen it then when it did.  A good movie with a decent storyline and cast.

Although this movie was touching,it was not interesting.  This despite the fact that the actors were excellent (of course).  The story line felt trite and it felt like a vehicle for a few actors to make a few more dollars.  It was OK and I recommend it if you need to fill a couple of hours with something that's a bit distracting.
It's worth one watch because of the comedy factor but the story is pretty lame.  As a MOPAR guy I enjoyed the SRT cameo.
I loved loved loved this movie.  I would watch this movie over and over again.  I like a nice amount of violence in a movie and this had just the right amount of violence and humor.

DISCLAIMER: If it weren't for Walken, this would be a two or three star film at best. Really Enjoyed This Movie Two Good From Friends From The Past Link Up Again After One Was Released From Prison And The Other Meeting Him At The Gate. I Won't Spoil It For You, Take A Chance And Watch It.

what a pos by a couple of old washed up actors. Save ur time or pick something else wast of time

I love these actors and they did not disappoint me~give it a try.

You know if this movie had more than half a script, it would have been great. The characters and situations were interesting enough, the acting OK, but they just didn't have enough to work with and the director probably contributed a bit to a way premature ending.
Very entertaining movie.  The plot line isn't anything to brag about, but to watch two iconic actors (and a third awesome one) just have fun in classic roles for them is very enjoyable.

When I see a new movie with the likes of a Pacino, Walken, or De Niro, I get the same feeling as when I watch a once-great athlete who is now in the twilight of his career. Sure, there are moments of greatness that remind you why you're watching a legend. However, those precious moments are inevitably weighed down by an overwhelming sense of fatigue.

So, it's perhaps befitting the characters in this movie are also in the final acts of their lives. Nevertheless, the fire and passion, to me anyway, is simply not there.

I'd recommend this movie if:

1) You're a dyed in the wool Pacino, Walken, or Arkin fan and you've seen all their earlier works (Serpico, Deer Hunter, etc.)

or

2) If you have a soft spot for the aging underdogs who show the world that old-school honor, that rare ability to steadfastly remain a stand-up guy, still means something.

Otherwise, be prepared for a trio of icons going through the motions of an unoriginal story.
Loved this film.  Even played back the eulogy Pacino said at Arkin grave because the words were so meaningful to me. It is worth the entertainment time spent.
Great movie - enjoyed every bit. Acting superb , story was great. So of predictable ending but a great movie.
We liked it. Al Pacino was very funny but the ending smells of sequel to follow. Good movie for adults only

As this heart-warming, tear-jerking, off-the-wall comedy picks up speed, you are drawn into an under-world of corruption, vengeance and remorse. The main characters, the antagonists, are more at war with time and aging than they are with each other. They are always striving for that elusive dream... To be relevant right up to the end.
Bravo, Well Done!
Richie
Love, Love, Love Love, Loved this movie. Huge Christopher Walken and Al Pacino fan. Don't need to say anything else.
I like both of these actors. But I had to stop after only 15 minutes. I agree with another writer where this movie was the only reason to get the two actors together.

As someone else described it: comfortable. This is the movie version of an old pair of shoes that are comfortable. You would never get excited about them or write about them. You just know that when you walk around in them you are not even paying attention to your feet. All three of these actors have been around forever and this film looks like it was just an excuse to get them together for a movie. It has some humor and some pathos. It is a bit hard to believe in certain places and it ends rather enigmatically. Not bad, not great. Good Saturday afternoon time filler.

Thank goodness it was free, at least I finished folding my laundry so it wasn't a total waste of my time.

The ending was predictable from the first diner scene.  Good actors in type-cast parts were able to propel this piece all the way to three stars.

A bunch of old criminals making a lat stand. Walken is probably at his dramatic best in this movie. The story line is pretty much a few criminal types did some things when they were younger and old age catches up to them. One of them was supposed to whack the other but wisdom seems to overtake the urgency and three guys set out to "even up the score." I don't want to give any of it away but take a look at the cast and rest assured you'll see some good acting and action. Not the best movie out there but entertaining and worth a watch.
A lot of laughs and a slightly different role for Al Pacino. You can root for the bad guys and still laugh!

It has been a long time since I have even wanted to rate or review a movie. I enjoyed this movie and will watch it again. Mostly enjoyed the true feeling of friendship between Doc and Val even after being apart for 28 years. I laughed and even wanted to cry at times. Felt very comfortable watching this film as it seemed to be a friend of mine telling me a story about their day. Have always enjoyed Walken's work, it always seems to me that he is always thinking what he wants to say where it comes out fair and even. Pacino is always a treat as he can really be a loose cannon. Alan Arkin played his part being the best straight man. Enough of this dribble let's go watch it again!

If you loved the classic Butch Cassidy & The Sundance Kid, you'll adore this movie.
Its about two old outlaws--and best friends--that go out like champs...instead of fade away into the oblivion of old age.  Good storyline with excellent acting from two masters of their craft.  This movie mixes good clean action with humor and touching moments.  Both guys and chicks can dig this flick...if you are over 40.  I doubt that those raised on inane senseless violence, graphic sex, and four letter words will appreciate Stand Up Guys....but those who like classic American movies will enjoy this unknown minor masterpiece.

With an unbalanced blend of quirky behaviors, costumes, set design, and plot, these most excellent actors and their lovely female supporting cast are left disconnected, askew, and without momentum.  You have to push the "I believe" button about 2,000 times to make sense of this.
Great film to watch. The pacing of it was very good. Good plot. Not too bad for a first time director.

The movie had some overall entertaining momemts, but very predictable.  The movie was OK but would have a hard time recommending it. The stars in the movie are among my favorites, but in many ways seemed to be going through the motions.

I was actually looking forward to this movie because of the cast. A crime comedy with a legendary cast, how could this possibly go wrong? Unfortunately, Stand Up Guys is a disaster.

Al Pacino and Christopher Walken try their best, but they have nothing to work with here. The script is awful and the two characters are lifeless, undeveloped, and have absolutely no chemistry with one another. The writing is surprisingly bad too with more than a handful of awful jokes that become increasingly irritating to listen to. There is a Viagra joke early on in the movie that is not only not funny, but has been ton a million times in other movies. Even worse, they milk the joke dry by forcibly bringing it up constantly within the first 30 minutes of the film. Alan Arkin has a very small role in the film and one of the few scenes he's in was one of the few parts I actually enjoyed in the film. The whole film is pretty much 90 minutes of "OH LOOK HOW OLD THESE ACTORS ARE HA HA HA", except none of the jokes are well-written and the film has no build up or pay off. It just keeps going on and on until it leads up to one of the worst most anti-climatic endings I've ever seen. The worst part of it might be though is having to watch these legendary actors go to new lows to the point where it becomes embarrassing to watch them.

. Don't waste your time with this one even if you're a fan of these actors.

I love Christopher Walken. He does not disappoint in this movie. Christopher, Doc, is a loyal friend to Al Pacino's, Val.

Doc and Val were stickup men and now are old men. Val is blamed for mob boss Claphand's son death in a robbery gone wrong and spent 28 years doing time for the crime. He always expected he'd be offed in the pen. Now as his term is complete and he's a free man. His best friend, Doc picks him up...he has 24 hrs. The next 24 hrs are a hilarious and entertaining story!

Most of the show you will laugh yourself off the couch. But be prepared for a few moments of rather repetitively annoying dialog. Val doesn't seem to know how to form a sentence without using efword multiple times in the same sentence. If the script were a bit stronger I would have given it a 5 out of 5 stars.

Starting off kind of dry, this movie quickly evolves into an entertaining show. Both primary actors have been friends of mine for decades, and now to see them in possibly one of their last performances, with a little humor thrown at aging, is truly a performance! This is for a time when you want to just watch a fun flick, and get a few laughs in.

we really enjoyed this movie and particularly because it was free with our Amazon Prime membership...let's have more like this

It wasn't what I had expected with the actors in it; a people movie.  I was expecting something like HEAT (great movie) with much action.  But I loved it.

I'm not sure what I expected, but it wasn't what I got from this movie. Granted, both Al Pacino and Christopher Walken are aging actors, so perhaps I was expecting too much.  This was much more of a drama than an action film, so I should read the description and genre more carefully before I decide to what a movie, regardless of who the actors are.  It was not a 'bad' movie but just not what I expected. They tried to make up for their lack of action with foul language and sexual content, which didn't work well for me with these two old guys!

While Pacino was relatively good, found it quite creepy how much they discussed sexual items such as Viagra and his 'Shwanz' Also, what the heck was with all the drug taking. Sure he is 'away' for 28 years. I guess it fits with the style he was accustomed too, just felt it took away from the movie - the director focused too much on the drugs.

The ending was cool. If you are going to go out, go out on your terms if you can help it. Also setting up the grand daughter!

Good acting all around.
was an okay movie... not ha ha funny though. I could have watched some thing else. watch if you like the actors

Of course I love the actors and I've noticed some of their older actors have been in some not so great movies as of late and want expecting much but it was as great as you would expect! Not boring like I thought it would be. Funny and very cute story. I loved it.

Pacino, Walken, Arkin, how could you go wrong? Not enough of Alan Arkin for starters. Weak and vague back story does not help in fleshing out the lead characters. The rest was OK, just OK. Director did a poor job of projecting the angst of Walken's character regarding his daughter. Still entertaining, but needed more. It might even need an entire prequel  to really flesh out the secondary characters as well.

The perfect movie for an old man like myself :-)  Good actors I've known for years, lots of action, a plot that's easy to follow (one I don't have to ask my wife to explain what's going on :-). It's a story of real loyalty among friends, something you don't see much of anymore.

There are plenty of other reviews here that rehash the plot. Read them if you want the spoilers.  Rotten Tomatoes gives it a 38% by the pro reviewers and 48% by the ordinary viewers. So that's the numbers for you. And I would agree that the screenplay is occasionally trite, cliche-ridden, or just written for the guffaw (the hospital scene, or the women's implausible ecstasy over the mnage  trois). And the pacing is slow.
"Is slow..." until you have given the three, Walken, Pacino, and Arkin, the time they need to "sell" you their characters, and you will be right there in the scene. If you want Plato's Republic on the meaning of life, go elsewhere, but these three actors show three different lives, portrayed within a time of 24 hours -- they present how each life was lived, and how they see themselves as having sometimes done right and sometimes having done what they now regret. The same words in another actor would sound like tin, but here you feel the weight and pain of each line. I cannot imagine the director nor the screen writer creating these characterizations, they had to come from the unique imagination of each of these fully-accomplished actors, no where else. It is this creation out of the ensemble which is breath-taking and unique; you can see how they reached beyond the dross that the director and screen writer gave them. Three other actors, even if accomplished, would have come up with a different movie.
Another review points out that these three are crooks, why should we care about lowlifes? Although the guys are criminals, and we never learn the depths of their criminality, Pacino's 'guy' lays out utterly clear, why life is a precious gift to each of us. How many of us forget that in the day-to-day?
And that you won't discover in a reviewer's percentage points.
Sorry - Only got about 15 minutes into it before I got bored and turned it off ... Perhaps it gets better, but it started slow. Never got to Alan Arkin.
Good movie but a little slow. Still kind of fun and worth seeing especially for free with Amazon Prime right now.

Vintage at it's best -

This was a well-written, somewhat low-key movie about ex-cons reuniting after one is released from prison. The free man is blackmailed into being the hit-guy to kill his best friend. The movie follows the tough decision process Christopher Walkin's character must make - whether or not to follow through with the hit. It's poignant and heart warming in a buddy sort of way. I loved it. Worth watching.
Just a very enjoyable movie about aging "outlaws".  These guys show that even as a bad guy, you must always have your honor and scruples.  Well done.

I don't watch a lot of movies...just finished Stand Up Guys, and I'm shocked at how well this was written, directed, and acted. I can't believe anyone gave this a 1, 2 or 3 stars. Dark. But, goodness, I loved these characters.

You think this movie is going to be a fun shoot 'em up gangster flick. Yet it turns out to be a poignant depiction of aging, the duration of friendships, and loyalty to those we love. This was a much less funny movie than I expected, and a much more feel good movie than I anticipated. This isn't a macho Charles Bronson/ Clint Eastwood flick. This is closer to a sweet date flick you can surprise a special Lady with. She'll never see the sentiments coming that this film delivers, at least not until the very end.

It is hard to dislike a film that stars Christopher Walken and Al Pacino. In addition to them, Stand Up Guys manages to have Alan Arkin (though his role is comparatively small). This means three Oscar winners in one movie. Filmmakers should be thankful for their luck.

There is not much plot in the film that unfolds like a stage play. In a nutshell, Stand Up Guys is about two aged former criminals: Doc (Walken), now retired, and Val (Pacino), who has just got out of prison after 28 years. But Doc is secretly ordered to kill his friend by his boss. This is going to be Vals last night, but what will Doc do when the time comes?

Acting is first-rate (as you expect) and dialogue is interesting, but we expect something more from these veterans, which director Fisher Stevens fails to deliver. Two main characters are believable thanks to the stars, but I didn't find them as interesting as some reviewers say probably because of some familiar elements (Viagra, dancing, etc.).

But there are some bigger problems about the film: its pace that is slack, and subplots that are weak. The film could have made better use of some episodes such as their old friend Hirch (Alan Arkin) or a naked woman in the truck. After all Stand Up Guys shows what these charismatic actors like Christopher Walken and Al Pacino can do, but most of us know that even before watching the film.

What a waste of stellar talent. I had just watched the recent buddy film, Last Vegas with DiNiro, Douglas, Freeman,& Kline and wanted to watch 'something' so had a free download and it's Pacino and Walken.  So, why not? Kind of sad, really. Pacino's character was off the chain with his snorting prescription drugs and gobbling Viagra. And burying their friend in the middle of the night, exactly how did that work? Everything about this movie felt dated ,dingy and sadly out of synch. It's an old film and pretty easy to rent so it's not like people will really need to read a review. But yeah? Why waste time when there are so many really good, well written, well-acted stories out there. In short, do yourself a favor and give it a pass.

Christopher Walken plays his best friend who has not done much other than wait for his his friend to get out.  Once out, we discover Walken's mission is to kill his best friend.  This is mostly dark comedy and done very well. There are a couple of surprises but for the most part, you know how it ends from the beginning. But the acting and the dialogue is outstanding. Alan Arkin is brilliant. There's just not enough of him in this movie. This is classic Pacino and classic Walken. It's just a fun movie.

I know the critics and many fans panned this movie, but my wife and I really enjoyed.  We are both mid 50's, so our lives have spanned the actors' careers (The Deer Hunter is still my favorite movie of all time), plus we have watched our parents age and pass, along with most of their generation.  The acting is excellent, even if it is overplayed at times.  You can tell these guys had a great time making this movie.  We especially liked the interaction between the generations; for all some people make about Gen X and Gen Y, there is less of a gap now than there was when I was in my 20's.  The story is fairly predictable and the ending typical Hollywood nonsense, but it was a fun watch.  We rented it, but we are going to buy it and watch it over at least once a year.

A student of screen writing would applaud the writers:  they hit all the bases.  Strong character development, the right amount of humor, the obligatory car chase, a nice assortment of subplots, and a competently twisted ending. That said, the student of screen writing can pretty much figure out the plot twists fairly quickly and watch the rest of the movie smugly thinking, "I coulda done that."  Too bad he didn't, huh? He wouldn't be writing movie reviews for Amazon.

I can give you my review in one sentence, then I'll provide some details:

"This one is going to be too subtle for a lot of people."

It's hard to discuss this one in detail without dishing up spoilers.

But here's one. Alan Arkin has just finished a tryst with a working girl and the owner of a brothel...the "menage a trois" he's had on his bucket list for years.

The owner tells him "You've ruined me for any other man."

Arkin replies "It's OK. You'll get over it."

The movie DOES start a little slow, primarily an interaction between Walken and Pacino, and after they "rescue" Arkin from a rest home (in a stolen car), things get NUTS. It is VERY subtle, tongue-in-cheek humor. It gets progressively weirder. But if you're looking for "Dumb and Dumber" you WILL get bored.

Listen, this isn't Gone With The Wind or Citizen Kane. It's an extremely eccentric mash-up between three legends. If you're in the mood for rapid-fire story lines and acting, watch something else, and when you're feeling like kicking back and letting the weirdness of this one slowly unfold, do it. It's FUNNY. It's worth your time, as long as you take the caveats above into consideration. I loved it, I'll be watching it a second time (at minimum).

Its probably time for some of the great actors to hang up their hats. This I think should be a swan song.
Entertaining enough.

You know those movies that are enjoyable, but they feel like they are building up to the end of the movie? That's how this movie is. It is enjoyable, but there is never that "awesome" moment. The awesome moment is cut off at the end of the movie, not leaving you with a feeling of "hooray, their story is just beginning," which I think is really the only reason to end a movie the way they did; no, this movie leaves you at the end of the movie....and they just cut it off! You feel cheated at the end, not entertained or anything else.  It's a shame, too. I really liked the rest of the movie. The characters are interesting and likable, and I even thought the story was well-done up until the end. It was the perfect "build up to an awesome end" type of movie...but NOPE, you get half of an ending, one that leaves you scratching your head and wondering, "What the heck were they thinking when they wrote this?"

TL;DR

A horrible ending invalidates an otherwise great movie. I think it's worth a watch (it's on Prime at the time of me writing this review, so you can maybe watch it), but there is no way I would buy this movie. I won't be watching it again.

I expected more from a movie with this outstanding ensemble of actors. I can only assume that the director was trying to make me feel as old and feeble as these now senior citizen gangsters who once ruled the roost. The overall movie was excruciatingly slow with rare moments of witty dialogue. It's hard to build a compelling story around boner pills, a lack of enthusiasm for criminal activity, a failed fatherhood, and multiple trips to a whorehouse. The merciful thing to do would have been to allow this movie to die in its sleep. Alan Arkin was the standout here with too little screen time.

It was a good movie and I would recommend it if you like these two stars.
It is funny and sad

Take a look at the one and two star reviews. They say things like "Banal," "pointless," "sentimental." Check, check and check. Throw in predictable, unbelievable and hokey.  But do yourself a favor anyway and take a look. From opening to closing, if you love Walken being Walken, Pacino doing his own impersonation, and a script that gives you a little bite out of everything you ever loved about their quirkier movies, you will spend a great 90 minutes here.

You could call the film quirky too.  Mostly because of Mr. Pacino's whatchamacallit... I don't know if Amazon will let me use the correct word, so let's just call it Thingy. After an overdose of stolen Viagra, it's almost a co-star.  But salaciousness is just a tiny ingredient in this half-baked but still delicious souffle.  Sure the plot is pointless, serving just as an excuse for our two guys to do some of their favorite shtick, and it goes well beyond blocked vein priapism (in case you wanted to know the medical term).  Walken and Pacino are old time gangsters, from back in the day when being a gangster meant something. Pacino has spent the better part of 30 years in prison. His partner in crime and best friend picks him out outside the walls and they spend a day on the town. Turns out, this is going to be Pacino's last day because his former boss wants him whacked ASAP and it's Walken's job to be the triggerman.

Stand Up Guys doesn't miss a trick. We have the Hooker with the Heart of Gold, the Truly Evil Villian, a granddaughter and grandfather reunion, the Geezers who can outshoot, outfight and out (another word I think Ammy might object to) guys half their age.  We have justice and revenge, tables turning, romance and regret.  We have humor, heartbreak, lots of action, dialogue that's a little familiar but enjoyable all the more for that reason, and a car chase that is the only one I have ever loved.  Throw in some good little cameos by Alan Arkin and Juliette Margulies...who also served as director of the flick, and you just have something endearing if not memorable.  Arkin, by the way, is very good, with some great lines.

Don't be a critic, don't be picky. If you liked Walken in his latter day gangster flicks (or even better, "$5 a day" take a chance on Stand Up Guys. By the way, "All out of gum" refers to their catchphrase. When pacino says "It's time to kick butt or chew gum," Walken provides the reply. Sometimes he even does a little dance.  That alone is worth a couple of stars.  Enjoy.
I love each of these actors. Each of them gave an awesome performance. I really enjoyed the movie. Highly recommended.
Wow that was a waste of time. Very lame story bad acting. It made no sense at all. Sorry about that

The actors are all pro's,  they can be entertaining selling garbage bags, This movie is better than a garbage bag,  its OK. First, I really loved this movie. It's a very fine piece of work, a good, entertaining movie that will keep you thinking. The writing is good, though the script doesn't deviate from the standard Hollywood canned meat that gets churned out. However, the acting is spellbinding, so strong and entrancing that the most mundane lines will have your riveted.

Second, though there are predictable Hollywood twists and turns that undermines the intellect of the film, the intelligence of the film still remains. There's layers of tension and mental conflict for the characters and the viewer.

My best endorsement, my wife and I went to bed talking about the film for 30 minutes. That seems to rarely happen these days. Watch and enjoy it!

I thought this film was OK as a film about some very pathetic people who have wasted their lives.  I liked the character Walken played and thought his acting was excellent.  The story felt padded with some sleazy sexual references and devoid of any real wisdom gained.  What I did like about the film was the redemption that the Walken character found through his painting and that he finally made contact with his daughter.  I thought the heavy shoot out at the ending, as the only option, devoid of any strategy was totally unrealistic and looked like some Hollywood director's idea of "what sells."  So it was thin on story, wisdom, and classbut there were a few laughs.  Would I purchase it again - No.  I think if this is the last film these fine actors make it is a lousy way to end their careers.  Hopefully it won't be.  Do I recommend it?  Wellnot really.

Real pros. They are the only ones who could carry this off. Especially Al Pacino and Christopher Walken. They don't have quite the same cutes that Paul Newman and Robert Redford did, or the youth, but they do pretty well, and this movie packs a harder punch in old age than Butch and Sundance could manage. And Pacino got to dance with his eyes open this time. I wish that Alan Arkin could have hung around longer, but I suppose three's a crowd.

"They say we die twice. Once when the breath leaves our body, and once when the last person we know says our name."--Valentino

The 2012 Fisher Stevens film, Stand Up Guys, has a strong cast. Bringing in $3 million at stand up guysthe box office, it was clearly something of a flop. Unfortunately, Al Pacino, Christopher Walken and Alan Arkin might not be the draw they once were. The 95 minute, Rated R mob-like movie was, if anything, consistent. Not great. Not horrible.

Valentino, "Val" to his friends -- Pacino to you and me, is just released from prison after 28 years locked away. "Doc" (Walken) meets him at the gate. Retired made-men, the two head back to Doc's, where a pull-out sofa bed is ready for Val. Having spent his retired days painting sunrises and sunsets, Doc is pretty set in his routine. A little frisky after decades behind bars, Val is hoping to party.

Nightclubs, and whore houses, some robbery and plenty of reminiscing is what unfolds. Doc was able to track down his daughter, but not his granddaughter. The regrets of his life apparent in his face, in his words, and even in his actions. Somewhat bitter, Val, was sent to prison and never talked. Never gave anyone up. Took the punishment all on his own.

Mark Margolis portrays the mob boss character, Claphands. He has not forgotten Val, or part of why Val was in prison. Claphands' only son was murdered by Val. The only fair thing is revenge. The clock is set. At 10:00 AM, Val will be dead. One way or the other.

Enter Alan Arkin as Hirsch. Doc and Val rescue their old time friend from a retirement home. They steal a Mustang, and they paint the town red. That is, until they find a surprise in the trunk of the vehicle. And then participate in serving up some serious justice.

Many scenes, I hate to admit are just over acted by Pacino. However, the story continues to move forward.  It is often touching and slightly emotional. It is often humorous and slightly compelling. Overall it is a solid rental, or Netflix kind of film. I did not play with my phone, or scroll statuses on Facebook. It's how I rate a film, people. For these reasons, and the simple respect for the cast, I am giving Stand Up Guys 4 out of 5 stars. Why 4? Because it really was a pretty good film. Not great. But Pretty good. (Lots of bad language, some violence, No Nudity).

I think the director shares some of the blame for not getting better performances from the lead characters and working with the writer to induce some life into the story. Unlike the Dodge Hemi powered Challanger SR/T they steal this movie isn't running on all 8 cylinders instead it's running roughly on 3 cylinders. It spits, sputters, coughs and spews raw fuel at it crawls along trying to be funny, touching, tough and in the end needed, but dies alongside the road with it's flashers on waiting for a tow. You know, one beef I have with this movie is the inaccuracy in which the mafia is portrayed.  No matter how much mafia movies Hollywood creates, they always manage to get the facts wrong.  Two inaccuracies I caught in this movie was Al's character, Val, going into a confessional and confessing that he had committed crimes.  In real life, that wouldn't happen.  Another part was the fact that Christopher's character never killed Val.  In real life he would've whacked Val not matter how close of a friend he is.  Other than that, it's a descent movie.

I've gotten to the point in my life that I just can't get much sentimentality going for bad guys. "Stand Up Guys" was created with a good deal of material that drips with ill applied attempts at misty-eyed moments. Walken and Pacino play aged and "washed up" criminals well, but their internal struggles with family and age are more of a 'who cares' when it boils down to knowing that these mutts had a very immoral and illegal history.

The entertainment value is not in the characters losses or inner turmoils, but in who they ARE now. The comedy of errors is the key to liking this film.  The first half hour is drab with Pachino doing some weird stuff like snorting prescription meds and trying to turn on today's young girls with old school moves. It was bombing so bad I almost turned off the DVD player.

Eventually, a nice stride kicked in and the film became a strange fixation as the two stars street antics became funny and interesting. The arrival of Alan Arkin made for a chemistry fueled trio that increased the chuckle level, sustaining the film. I was also surprised by the solid action sequences and capable posturing by the main stars. It's all more than a bit stagey and full of itself , and from this you get a mediocre film that is unlikely to reach the broadest of audiences.

The Guys this movie centers around are old crime buddies reunited after one, Val, is released from a 28-year prison stay, so the plot comes across as an epilogue. Their most thrilling days are behind them, but still they manage to get into plenty of mischief in just a matter of hours. The gist is that Doc has been ordered by his crime boss to kill Val by 10-AM, something he's only reluctantly going along with in order to save his own life. Val killed the boss's son before going to prison, and the boss wants revenge, so if Doc backs out, he too will be killed.

That revelation brings with it a certain level of underlying tension, despite the fact that Doc immediately admits to Val what's going on the moment he gets suspicious enough to ask about it. And tension, however weak, in a movie is a good thing. The problem is that the plot, which often runs in real time, has nowhere to go from there. 10-AM is the deadline and Doc makes it obvious he's going to wait until then to do it, but the random things they do in the meanwhile; this flick is much better at drama than comedy; only strains the plausibility of the plot.

I have to put this film in the same folder with "Good Fellas", "The Godfather" etc; it is the logical conclusion, the final chapter of a mobster's life. Don't expect a whole lot of murder and guns, there is some of that but it isn't a Quentin Tarantino type thing at all. I won't give away the plot, but it's basically about the lifelong friendship of two 'made guys' and their last day together. One did a long stretch in the joint because he took a fall for the mob; the other went into a regulated sort of retirement, trying to carve a somewhat normal life out of his former occupation. Related to some sins of the distant past, one is ordered to kill the other. The path to the finish line is poignant, sad, interesting and at times laugh-out-loud funny.
